poem:
Title: "Interlaced in Bristol"

Amid Bristol streets, a tale untwined,
with diasporic pulse and Jamaican rhyme.
Feel Somalian sun, whispers in wind,
Olive orchards reckon the time.

An audacious script, as Dickens inscribed,
Waldegrave's voice in chorus sing.
Their roots engraved on British soil,
McKenzie's blossoms in spring.

Truth and triumph, in Ends they grove,
This Olive-tale, a testament of love.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Moses McKenzie: ‘I was thinking about the predicament of the black British diaspora’ Moses McKenzie, 26, won last year’s Hawthornden prize, previously awarded to Hilary Mantel and Ali Smith, for his 2022 debut, An Olive Grove in Ends, set among Jamaicans and Somalis in Bristol, where he grew up. William Waldegrave, a Tory MP in the city from 1979 to 1997, wrote in the New Statesman that the novel was “astonishing... rather as Dickens introduced". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
